Understanding the structure-activity relationship of catalysis is of critical importance for the design and modulation of catalysts. Herein, Cu-Al spinel catalysts with varied Mg doping levels were synthesized and investigated for CO hydrogenation to dimethyl ether (DME). The results revealed that the coordination distribution of cations in catalysts was effectively regulated by controlling Mg content. Increasing the Mg content facilitated the migration of Cu2+ ions in catalysts from tetrahedral to octahedral sites, enhancing the sustained release performance of copper, and further promoting the stabilization role of Cu nanoparticles by spinel. Importantly, suitable Mg content enhanced the synergistic effect between Cu nanoparticles and spinel active sites, which was conducive to improving DME selectivity. However, excessive Mg doping suppressed the reduction of copper species, and also adversely generated excessive strong base sites. Consequently, an optimal Mg/(Mg+Cu) mole ratio of 0.15 over the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst exhibited superior selectivity to DME at 64.2 % (at 48 h) and excellent stability during the continuous testing for 120 h. The In-situ DRIFTS experiment confirmed that this reaction involved CH3O* intermediates, and the pathway was elucidated as the hydrogenation of CH3O* to form CH3OH and further dehydration to generate CH3OCH3. Introduction The development of syngas catalytic conversion technology provides an attractive process route for the production of alternative fuels, which not only reduces the consumption and dependence on oil resources, but also alleviates environmental pollution [1–3]. Specifically, dimethyl ether (DME) is a low polluting feedstock in the chemical industry. Due to its high cetane number, low NOx emissions as well as less engine noise, it is considered as a prospective renewable alternative fuel for diesel and liquefied petroleum gas [8]. Additionally, DME serves as an efficient hydrogen-rich carrier for fuel cells [4–6]. The direct catalytic conversion of syngas to DME is of great significance as it can efficiently produce DME utilizing its thermodynamic advantages [7–9]. In recent studies, a new material of copper-based spinel catalyst with a face-centered cubic structure has been proposed. In this structure, Cu2+ ions are automatically separated by metal oxides, which is conducive to exerting their unique sustained release performance and exhibiting excellent catalytic stability on copper-based spinel catalysts [10]. Moreover, a study has shown that Cu-Al spinel catalysts exhibit significant superiority in catalytic activity and regeneration ability as compared to commercial Cu-Zn-Al catalysts [11]. The Cu-Al spinel belongs to a typical non-stoichiometric spinel, whose chemical structural formula is Td(Cu1‑ x Al x )Oh(Cu x Al2‑ x )O4 with x denoting inversion degree (0 < x < 1), wherein Cu2+ and Al3+ ions occupy in different ratios both octahedral and tetrahedral interstices [12]. The structure of catalysts is largely influenced by process conditions. The research finding indicates that calcination temperature, molar ratio of metal, and the introduction of foreign cations have a regulatory effect on the structure of spinel [13–16]. In our previous work, we found that the coordination distribution of cations in spinel structure has a significant impact on the catalytic activity and stability of CO hydrogenation to DME. Intriguingly, the occupation of cations in spinel structure is readily tuned by changing the preparation method, and DME selectivity is further improved by increasing the content of octahedral spinel Cu2+ ions [17]. Additionally, the microstructure of catalysts is also capable of being adjusted by introducing foreign metals as structural promoters, which dramatically affects the properties of catalysts, further impacting on its catalytic performance. For instance, Tian et al. synthesized a series of spinel catalysts with different K doping levels and found that K dopant promoted active cations migrating from tetrahedron to octahedron sites. This significantly enhanced the degree of cation disordered distribution in the spinel structure, thereby producing more oxygen vacancies as well as defects, which lowers the activation energy for generating isobutanol and improves the isobutanol fraction for CO hydrogenation reaction [18]. Mg2+ is regard as a promising the structural promoter and has a strong stabilizing effect on Cu species, decreasing Cu particle size and improving Cu dispersion, thus exhibiting higher activity and stability [19]. Dasireddy et al. suggested that adding Mg2+ into Cu/Al2O3 catalysts can generate more active sites [20]. Despite massive research focus on the surface modification of Cu/Zn/Al catalysts by MgO, few reports concentrate on the effect of MgO on the structural regulation of Cu-Al spinel catalyst. Notably, whether the more octahedral Cu2+ ions in catalysts are advantageous for CO hydrogenation to DME, which demands to be further investigated. Herein, a series of Cu-Al spinel catalysts with a small amount of Mg2+ doping are prepared using a facile and green method (solid-phase method). Based on the analysis of structure and physicochemical properties, the structure-activity relationship is established, which provides strategies for devising more efficient catalysts. This work focuses on the synergistic effect between Cu nanoparticles and CuMgAl spinel during the reaction process. Additionally, the reaction mechanism of synthesizing DME from syngas is elucidated by in-situ DRIFTS. Experimental Catalyst preparation The catalysts were synthesized via a solid-phase method. Briefly, copper hydroxide, magnesium carbonate, and pseudo-boehmite powders were initially mixed, followed by the mixed powders being ball milled for 6 h and calcined for 3 h at 1173 K under air atmosphere. After that, the final Cu1-xMgxAl2O4 at a constant (Cu+Mg)/Al mole ratio of 1/2 were obtained, in which x represented the mole ratio of Mg/(Mg+Cu). According to the amount of Mg addition, the x value was set as 0.05, 0.1, 0.15 and 0.25, which were labeled as C0.95M0.05A2, C0.9M0.1A2, C0.85M0.15A2 and C0.75M0.25A2, respectively. Catalyst characterization The XRD patterns were acquired with the Rigaku X-ray diffractometer operating at 40 kV and 40 mA, equipped with the Cu-Kα radiation source, and a scanning rate of 8°/min in the 2θ range of 5 − 85°. UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy of samples was analyzed employing the Thermo Evolution 220 spectrometer, and BaSO4 was used as the reference. The 27Al-MAS-NMR experiment was performed on Bruker AV-III 600 using a small-flip angle probe at the spinning rate of 14 kHz. The chemical shift of 27Al-MAS-NMR was referenced to 1 mol/L Al(NO3)3 aqueous at 0 ppm. N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was carried out on a Micromeritics ASAP 2000 instrument. All samples were degassed for 4 h under vacuum prior to measurement. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of catalysts were analyzed by Brunauer−Emmet−Teller (BET) equation and Barret−Joyner−Halenda (BJH) method, respectively. The average chemical content of catalysts was measured by X-ray fluorescence (XRF) on Epsilon1 using Ag radiation produced at 50 kV and 100 μA with a SDD5 detector. H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) was performed on a TP-5080 chemisorption instrument. Before the analysis, 50 mg of catalyst was firstly purged in He flow up to 423 K and kept for 30 min, followed by cooling to 323 K. Then, the reducing gas (5 % H2/Ar) was introduced and the temperature was raised at a ramping rate of 10 K·min−1 up to 1173 K. The hydrogen consumption was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) experiment was carried out using a Thermo Scientific K-Alpha+ instrument equipped with a monochromatized Al Kα X-ray radiation source (hv =1486.6 eV). All the binding energy was calibrated according to the standard binding energy of C1s (284.8 eV). The temperature-programmed desorption of NH3/CO2 (NH3/CO2-TPD-MS) analysis was conducted on Bayer BELCAT-B apparatus. Firstly, the spent sample (50 mg) was purged with He at 553 K for 30 min and cooled to 323 K. Followed by proceeding to NH3/CO2 adsorption at 323 K for 30 min. The desorbed NH3/CO2 was collected with a mass spectrometer (MS). The morphology of the spent catalyst surface was studied by scanning electron microscope (SEM) analysis produced by Hitachi Regulus 8100, fitted with an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyzer to evaluate element distribution. The information of microstructure and Cu particle size was analyzed by transmission electron microscope (TEM) on a US FEI Talos 200× instrument. The Cu dispersion (D Cu), exposed Cu surface area (S Cu), and Cu particle size ( d Cu N 2 O ) were measured by N2O titration on the Xian Quan TP-5080D chemisorption analyzer. The samples were pretreated at 423 K under flowing N2 for 30 min and further cooled down at 323 K. After that, the samples were firstly reduced in flowing 5 % H2/N2 at 783 K, and the H2 consumption detected by TCD was denoted as A 1 (mmolg−1). The samples were flushed with N2 to remove adsorbed H species, and the temperature was cooled to 323 K under N2, followed by introducing 5 % N2O/N2 (30 mL/min) to oxidize surface Cu0 into Cu2O, then the gas was switched to N2 stream for 30 min to remove residual N2O. The Cu2O on the catalyst surface was again reduced to Cu0 with 5 % H2/N2 flowing under the same conditions as the first reduction process, and the H2 consumption detected by TCD was denoted as A 2 (mmolg−1). The Cu dispersion (D Cu), Cu surface area (S Cu), and Cu particle size ( d Cu N 2 O ) were calculated using the following formulas: [21] (1) D Cu = 2 × A 2 / A 1 × 100 % (2) S Cu = 2 × A 2 × N av / ( A 1 × M Cu × 1.4 × 10 19 ) = 1353 × A 2 / A 1 ( m 2 / g Cu ) (3) d Cu N 2 O = 6 / ( S × ρ Cu ) ≈ 0.5 × A 1 / A 2 ( nm ) N av was the Avogadro number, which was generally taken as 6.02×1023 atoms mol−1, M Cu was the relative atomic mass of Cu (63.54 g/mol), 1.4 × 1019 was the number of copper atoms per square meter (atoms/m2), ρ Cu was 8.92 g/cm3. In-situ DRIFTS spectroscopy was measured on a Bruker V ertex-70 infrared spectrometer with a DTGS detector (4 cm−1 resolution, 64 scans). Catalytic performance measurements The catalytic performance was investigated in a fixed-bed reactor with four stainless steel tubes. 3 mL catalyst of quantitative mass (40−60 mesh) was loaded in the constant temperature zone of each reactor. All catalysts were carried out without pre-reduction, and the feed syngas (H2/CO=2/1) was introduced into the reactor with a constant gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of 2000 h−1 and performed at 553 K and 4.0 MPa. The four reactors reacted simultaneously, and the products were quantitatively analyzed online by a Huaai GC-9560 gas chromatography based on the external standard method. The H2, CO, and CO2 were analyzed by a TCD detector, and the hydrocarbon (CnHm), CH3OH, and DME of outlet gas were analyzed by an FID detector. The liquid products were collected per 24 h and analyzed offline by the FID detector. The CO conversion and the selectivity of products were calculated after the carbon balance as follows: (4) X CO = ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) n ( CO ) in × 100 % (5) S i = n i ( g ) + n i ( l ) ∑ n i ( g ) + ∑ n i ( l ) × 100 % Where n i was carbon moles of a certain product i, n(CO)in was molar number of CO in feed gas. The space-time yields of DME (STY DME) was obtained by the following equation, denoting the amounts of DME produced per gram catalyst per hour. (6) S T Y DME = F CO , in · X CO · S DME m cat ( mmol · g − 1 · h − 1 ) In which F co,in was molar flow of CO into the reactor in mmol per hour, mcat was the mass of catalyst in grams, X co was CO conversion, S DME was DME selectivity. Results and discussions Spinel structure characterization Phase structure analysis The XRD patterns of the fresh catalysts with different Mg contents are presented in Fig. 1 a. The strong diffraction peaks appearing at 31.4º(220), 36.9º(311), 44.9º(400), 55.8º(422), 59.5º(511), and 65.4º(440) for all catalysts roughly correspond to the stoichiometric CuAl2O4 (PDF No.76–2295) and MgAl2O4 (PDF No.84–0377) spinel phase. This implies that the samples we synthesized may belong to CuMgAl spinel solid solution, that is non-stoichiometric CuMgAl spinel. Additionally, the weak diffraction peaks are observed at 35.6° and 38.7°, which is assigned to CuO (PDF No.80–1917), whereas no obvious MgO crystalline phases is detected. Notably, the Mg2+ ions existed in highly dispersed state or entered the spinel matrix are below the range of XRD detection. This indicates that partial Mg2+ ions migrate into the spinel lattice and the other Mg2+ ions exist in highly dispersed form, which is consistent with subsequent XPS analysis. The part of Cu2+ ion replaced by Mg2+ detach from the spinel phase and exist in the form of CuO. To clearly display the variation of CuMgAl spinel phase structure due to Mg2+ cations gradual incorporation into spinel framework, the (400) crystal plane of spinel is magnified as shown in Fig. 1b. We observe that the diffraction peaks of 400 crystal plane shift to a greater value of 2-theta until reaching a maximum of 44.96° with an increase in Mg/(Cu+Mg) molar ratio, and this variation tendency is inversing to the variation of corresponding lattice parameter a (Table 1 ), indicating that spinel phase occurs lattice distortion owing to the incorporation of partial Mg2+ ions into spinel lattice, which can be supported by 27Al MAS NMR characterization. Additionally, the lattice parameter of samples and two stoichiometric spinel reference values are compared, and the results indicate that the lattice parameter of samples is smaller than that of the stoichiometric CuAl2O4 (8.086 Å, PDF No.76–2295) and MgAl2O4 (8.080 Å, PDF No.84–0377), which further proves the formation of non-stoichiometric CuMgAl spinel phase. The XRD patterns of spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 1c. New diffraction peaks appear approximately at 2-theta values of 43.4º, 50.5º, and 74.2º, ascribing to the (111), (200), and (220) crystal planes of metal Cu0 (PDF No.99–0034), respectively. We observe that the diffraction peak of CuO disappears after the reaction, while the CuMgAl spinel diffraction peak weakens, which indicates the reduction of CuO and partial spinel Cu2+to Cu0, and the retained spinel phase after the reaction is relatively stable. Notably, the (111) crystal plane of Cu0 overlaps with MgO diffraction peak at 2-theta value of 43.4º [22]. The subsequent XPS analysis further proves the fact that MgO exists after the reaction. Coordination structure analysis The coordination distribution of Cu2+ ions in the samples is determined by UV–vis characterization. As seen in Fig. 2 a, all catalysts exhibit two absorption bands in the spectra, appearing at around 1500 nm and 778 nm, which is attributed to Cu2+ ions located in tetrahedral and octahedral interstices, respectively [23]. The results qualitatively show that all catalysts contain both tetrahedral Cu2+ and octahedral Cu2+. Notably, the absorption band intensity of tetrahedron Cu2+ ions progressively weakens with the further incorporation of Mg, while that of octahedron Cu2+ ions enhances correspondingly, illustrating that with the increase of Mg content, the tetrahedral Cu2+ gradually decreases, while the octahedral Cu2+ accordingly increases. In addition, the 27Al MAS NMR experiment is carried out to investigate the coordination environment of Al3+ ions in the samples, and the spectra are presented in Fig. 2b. The resonance absorption bands at ca. 8 ppm and 90 ppm correspond to octahedron Al3+ ions and tetrahedron Al3+ ions, respectively [24]. The relative content of Al3+ distribution is calculated by integrating the area of signal peaks, and quantitative results are shown in Fig. 2c. The results indicate that octahedron Al3+ ions predominate in the samples, but Al3+ ions gradually migrate from octahedron sites to tetrahedron sites with the increase of Mg content. Therefore, UV–vis and 27Al MAS NMR characterizations demonstrate that the doping of Mg regulates the cation occupation in the catalysts, which may further affect the physicochemical properties of catalysts. Pore structure analysis The N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms and pore-size distribution curves of various fresh samples are displayed in Figure S1, and the relevant textural parameters summarized in Table S1. As illustrated in Figure S1a, the type IV N2 isotherms with H3-shaped hysteresis loops are observed from the patterns, which reveals all synthesized catalysts exist mesoporous structure. From the results, we observe that the V BJH displays first marginally decline from 0.124 cm3/g to 0.120 cm3/g, followed by an increase to 0.156 cm3/g with the further incorporation of Mg component, which is accordance with the variation of S BET and D BJH. Among them, the largest specific surface area of 15.56 m2/g and V BJH of 0.156 cm3/g are obtained over the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst, which indicates that a higher Mg content is capable of significantly enhancing S BET and V BJH. From the Figure S1b, the results of pore analysis indicates that all catalysts exist a wide pore size distribution of 2.8‒133.4 nm, exhibiting one peak centered approximately at 30.5 nm. Also, we note that the most probable pore diameters of all catalysts are not significantly different, ranging from 30.24 nm to 31.48 nm. It is reported that the increase of specific surface area is favorable for exposing more active sites and improving catalytic performance [25]. Nevertheless, the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst displays relatively poor catalytic activity according to the activity data, illustrating that the specific surface area has little effect on catalytic performance. Spinel properties characterization Elemental composition and reducibility analysis The actual elemental composition of bulk in the fresh catalysts is measured by XRF experiment, as shown in Table 1. As expected, the results indicate that the proportion of Cu, Mg, and Al elements in the catalysts basically consistent with the initial feed ratios overall. The H2-TPR experiment is performed to assess the impact of Mg addition amount on the reduction behavior of fresh catalysts (Fig. 3 ). The samples exhibit multiple reduction peaks within the temperature range of 50−860 °C, illustrating the presence of multiple types of copper species reduction. Specifically, the reduction curve between 160 °C and 310 °C (region α) corresponds to the reduction of free CuO and/or Cu-O-Al intermediates [26], and the reduction peaks located in the temperature ranges of 310–530 °C (region β) and 530–860 °C (region γ) are attributed to easily-reducible spinel Cu2+ and non-easily-reducible spinel Cu2+ species, respectively [27]. As shown in Fig. 3a, with an increase in Mg/(Mg+Cu) molar ratio, the peak center of easily-reducible spinel gradually shifts towards higher temperature, accompanied by the appearance of non-easily-reducible spinel (for specific details see Fig. 3b). Overall, the degree of uneasy reducibility of spinel (including easily-reducible and non-easily-reducible spinel) follows the consequence of C0.75M0.25A2 > C0.85M0.15A2 > C0.9M0.1A2 > C0.95M0.05A2, which may be caused by that the introduction of Mg alters the coordination environment of Cu2+ ions. Coupled with the results of UV–vis characterization, it suggests that octahedron Cu2+ ions can delay the reduction of copper in samples as compared to the tetrahedron Cu2+ ions, which is consistent with previous research results. This is mainly attributed to the surface bonding strength of Cu2+ ion located in octahedral sites is larger than that in tetrahedral sites [28]. Furthermore, the proportion of CuO and spinel Cu2+ is calculated based on H2 consumption, and the results are listed in Table 2 . Notably, the proportion of spinel Cu2+ is over 90 %, illustrating that spinel Cu2+ species play a major role throughout catalytic reaction. XPS analysis As plotted in Fig. 4 , the chemical composition of the catalyst surface is analyzed by XPS characterization. The Mg 2p spectra in Figure 4(a-b) exhibit two binding energy peaks centered at ca. 49.8 eV and 51.2 eV, which are attributed to MgO and spinel Mg2+, respectively. Specifically, as shown in Fig. 4a, the Mg species are predominantly enriched on the surface of fresh catalyst in the form of MgO, with a small amount of Mg2+ ions entering the spinel lattice. After calculation, the relative content of MgO and spinel Mg2+ in spent catalysts (Fig. 4b) are listed in Table 2, and it is observed that the amount of spinel Mg2+ presents a tendency to increase initially and then decline with the increase of (Mg/Cu+Mg) molar ratio, in which the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst exhibits the highest amount of spinel Mg2+ at 32.17 %. The above analysis reveals the presence of both MgO and spinel Mg2+ in the fresh and spent catalysts. To clearly display the variation of Cu species in fresh and spent catalysts (Fig. 4c), taking the representative C0.85M0.15A2 as an example, the Cu 2p measurement are performed, where the Cu 2p binding energy exhibits peaks at 929−945 eV and 948−965 eV, corresponding to Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2, respectively. The main peak of Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2 are deconvolved into two peaks by means of peak fitting, where spinel Cu2+ located at 934.2 eV and 954.2 eV and CuO centered at 933.1 eV and 953.0 eV are observed, respectively [29,30]. As illustrated in Fig. 4c, Cu species on the fresh catalyst surface primarily exist in the form of spinel Cu2+, with a small amount of CuO. After 120 h of reaction evaluation, the two prominent peaks at 932.3 eV and 952.2 eV correspond to Cu0/Cu+ in Cu 2p 3/2 and Cu 2p 1/2, respectively [31]. Compared to fresh catalyst, the peaks of CuO disappear in spent catalyst, but a small amount of spinel Cu2+remains, indicating that CuO and partial spinel Cu2+ are reduced to Cu0 or/and Cu+, which implies spinel exists stably after releasing partial copper, which is in accordance with the above XRD results. Meanwhile, as shown in Fig. 4d, the Al 2p spectra exhibit two peaks around 74.61 eV and 77.31 eV in the fresh and spent C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst, corresponding to spinel Al3+ and Cu 3p, respectively [26]. This further confirms the presence of the CuMgAl spinel phase in both fresh and spent C0.85M0.15A2 catalysts, which is supported by the above XRD results. Surface acidity and basicity analysis The surface acidity of catalysts is a key factor for DME synthesis from syngas. The NH3-TPD-MS experiment is performed to investigate the surface acidity of the spent catalysts, and desorption profiles are exhibited in Fig. 5 a and the amount of NH3 desorption on the spent catalysts is quantitatively evaluated in Table S2. It is observed that all catalysts display two NH3 desorption peaks, indicating the existence of two distinctive types of acid sites: the desorption peaks around 80−160 °C (T1) and 320−540 °C (T2) correspond to the weak and strong acid sites, respectively [32,33]. The number of strong acid sites is much higher than that of weak acid sites for all catalysts. Moreover, with the further doping of magnesium, the desorption temperature of the T2 region slightly shifts towards a lower temperature overall and the corresponding amount of strong acid gradually decreases, which aligns with the variation trend of total acid amount, indicating that the surface acidity of the catalysts weakens during the process of progressively increasing Mg content. The previous studies have shown that the weak acidic sites are active sites for methanol dehydration to DME and is responsible for the enhanced DME production [34–37], while the strong acid sites are active centers for methanol dehydration forming hydrocarbon [38,39]. In this study, the weak acid amounts follow the sequence: C0.9M0.1A2>C0.85M0.15A2>C0.75M0.25A2>C0.95M0.05A2. However, the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst possesses the highest DME selectivity based on the following activity data, indicating that an appropriate amount of weak acid is favorable for improving DME selectivity. Besides, the C0.95M0.05A2 catalyst possesses numerous strong acidic sites, obtaining higher hydrocarbon selectivity, which coincides with the previous reports [34]. To further explore the effect of Mg additive amount on the surface basicity of catalysts, CO2-TPD-MS experiment is conducted on various spent catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5b, the profiles display two main desorption peaks: a low temperature desorption peak (T1) below 330 °C and a high temperature desorption peak (T2) between 330−650 °C, which are ascribed to weak and strong basic sites, respectively [40]. The CO2 desorption amounts of catalytsts are summarized in Table S2. The results reveal that the basicity strength of the catalysts is closely dependent on the content of Mg addition. Among them, C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst exhibits the maximum CO2 desorption at strong basic sites, suggesting that the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst surface contains the more strong basic sites, which may be related to massive free MgO on the catalyst surface according to the XPS results. Based on activity data, compared with the other three catalysts, C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst obtains lower DME selectivity, which may be due to that the presence of numerous strong base sites in the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst leads to a decline in DME selectivity. Properties of the released metal Cu Morphology and element distribution analysis Fig. 6 exhibits SEM images of different morphologies on the representative spent C0.95M0.05A2 and C0.85M0.15A2 catalysts. As depicted in Fig. 6a, the spent C0.95M0.05A2 catalyst displays irregular blocky structures formed by particle accumulation, whereas the spent C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst is comprised of numerous homogeneous granular-like structures (Fig. 6b). Additionally, an evident difference is observed in EDS-mapping images, the elemental distribution of C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst is more uniform compared to the C0.95M0.1A2 catalyst. It is indicated that the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst achieves higher proximity between the Cu, Mg, Al, and O components, which favors enhancing the interaction among various components in the catalyst. The mapping images further reveal that increasing the amount of Mg contributes to improving the dispersion of catalyst, which is supported by the subsequent TEM and N2O titration analyses. Fig. 7 displays the TEM and HRTEM micrographs of the spent C0.95M0.05A2 and C0.85M0.15A2 samples and the corresponding Cu particle size. As shown in Fig. 7a, the spent C0.95M0.05A2 catalyst exhibits amorphous granules, with the majority of particles aggregating to form irregularly shaped large nanoparticles. However, the TEM images of spent C0.85M0.15A2 (Fig. 7b) show well-dispersed spherical nanoparticles (NPs). This observation indicates that increasing the Mg content is conducive to improving the dispersion of Cu NPs (dark area), which is consistent with the SEM analysis results. Subsequently, HRTEM analysis is conducted for the two catalysts, as depicted in Fig. 7c and d. The lattice spacings of 0.205 nm, 0.465 nm, and 0.246 nm are detected in both catalysts, corresponding to the Cu0(111), Cu1-xMgxAl2O4(111), and MgO(111) crystal planes, respectively [26,41]. Combining this information with the images in Figs. 7b and d, it can be observed that the Cu NPs are supported on the surface of Cu1-xMgxAl2O4, which further indicates that the Cu NPs are stabilized by CuMgAl spinel. Previous studies have suggested that vacancies generated on the surface of spinel may play a key role in anchoring the released Cu NPs [26]. The wide size distributions in the range of 5 − 25 nm and 4 − 19 nm for the two catalysts are observed (Fig. 7e and f), with the average Cu particle size of the spent C0.95M0.05A2 and C0.85M0.15A2 catalysts measured as 13.8 nm and 10.3 nm, respectively. N2O titration analysis The N2O titration experiment is performed to further determine the dispersion (D Cu) and surface area (S Cu) of copper, as well as the released Cu particle size ( d Cu N 2 O ) from catalysts, as shown in Table 3 . Several times for N2O titration measurements are conducted to control weighing errors. Overall, it can be observed that both D Cu and S Cu increase with increasing Mg content, and the average particle size is in the range of 8.5 − 12.8 nm. Coupled with the results of H2-TPR and UV–vis, we found that the tetrahedral Cu2+ ions display the relatively readily reducibility as compared to the octahedral Cu2+ ions, thus indicating that tetrahedral Cu2+ ions is more easily to release Cu particles than that of octahedral Cu2+ ions. Importantly, the release process of copper species from spinel catalysts is described as the slow release of single Cu atom from the spinel structure, gradually forming nanoparticles through clustering [17]. Notably, the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst exhibits a relatively low copper release due to the large amounts of non-easily-reducible spinel, which delays its transition to the larger nanoparticle stage. Consequently, more smaller Cu NPs size (8.5 nm) is obtained, whereas its corresponding D Cu and S Cu values are the largest (11.7 % and 79.6 m2/g, respectively), and this is explicated that Cu surface area expectedly increases with Cu dispersion, which is related to Mg contents rather than depending on Cu release amount. It is worth noting that the Cu particle size measured from the N2O titration method in the spent C0.95M0.05A2 and C0.85M0.15A2 catalysts is lower than that calculated by the TEM, due to N2O is capable to capture segregated Cu atoms or small Cu clusters. Therefore, the Cu particle size determined by the N2O titration method is considered to be closer to the real state, as also indicated by previous researchers [42]. Subsequent discussions the effect of Cu particle size on catalytic activity will primarily be based on the size determined through the N2O titration method. Activity and stability measurements The CO hydrogenation performance of C1-xMxA2 catalysts is evaluated under the reaction conditions of 553 K, 4.0 MPa, H2/CO = 2/1, and GHSV=2000 h−1, and the evaluation results are presented in Fig. 8 . As shown in Fig. 8, compared to the other three catalysts, C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst maintains the higher activity during the 120 h time on stream (TOS), mainly manifested by the higher selectivity to DME at 64.2 % (at 48 h) and higher CO conversion, and fewer by-products (hydrocarbons and CO2). At 120 h, the DME selectivity of C0.95M0.05A2 and C0.9M0.1A2 is 26.3 % and 43.2 %, respectively, with the CO conversion of C0.9M0.1A2 being higher among the two catalysts. However, the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst shows poor activity and stability, with a maximum DME selectivity of only 24.7 % at 24 h. Furthermore, the DME selectivity dramatically decreases from 18.6 % at 96 h to 13.8 % at 120 h, with the byproducts (hydrocarbons and CO2) reaching approximately 80 % at 120 h. These results indicate that an appropriate Mg additive amount is instrumental in enhancing activity and stability, while the excessive Mg additive amount leads to a significant decrease in activity. The reasons for this difference will be subsequently discussed. Correlations between Cu surface area, Cu particle size, and space-time yield of DME As illustrated in Fig. 9 , it is evident that the space-time yield of DME (STY DME) shows a very clear dependence on the copper surface area (S Cu) and copper particle size ( d Cu N 2 O ), providing the Table 3 for detailed data. Briefly, except for the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst, the variation trend of STY DME and S Cu is consistent, inversing to that of d Cu N 2 O , revealing the structure sensitivity of this reaction. Smaller Cu particles achieve higher STY DME due to that smaller Cu NPs possess multitudinous open planes, with abundant edge or defect sites containing low-coordinated Cu [43], which leads to Cu NPs in close contact with the spinel, enhancing synergistic effect with the spinel. As a result, smaller Cu particles exhibit higher reactivity compared to large ones in the CO hydrogenation reaction. Additionally, a larger copper surface area (S Cu) facilitates the migration of dissociated hydrogen on the Cu surface and strong binding with the reaction intermediates, thereby reducing the activation energy [44–47]. It is reported that there is an approximate linear relationship between catalytic activity and copper surface area [48], illustrating that the copper surface area is also an important factor affecting catalytic performance. In this work, the C0.95M0.05A2, C0.9M0.1A2, and C0.85M0.15A2 catalysts exist this correlation. However, the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst is more pronounced in forming the smaller Cu particles and larger copper surface area, but its corresponding STY DME is the smallest, suggesting that S Cu and d Cu N 2 O are not responsible for low DME selectivity for C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst, which may be due to the lower copper release amounts. This conclusion is further supported by in-situ DRIFTS analysis. Fig. 10 Reaction mechanism To gain insight into investigating the reasons for the superior activity and stability of the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst and elucidate the reaction pathway of CO hydrogenation to DME on CuAlMg spinel catalysts, the in-situ DRIFTS analysis is performed on the fresh catalysts at 553 K, H2/CO=2/1, and 0.1 MPa. The bands appearing at 2170 cm−1 and 2117 cm−1 are assigned to gaseous CO and the linear absorption of Cu0-CO, respectively [49,50]. The infrared peak situated at 1028 cm−1 is attributed to CH3O* species, which originates from non-dissociative adsorbed CO hydrogenating on Cu sites [51]. One can be observed that the intensity of CH3O* gradually weakens in a short adsorption time, accompanied by the emergence of gaseous CH3OH (1141 cm−1). This indicates that CH3O* has a strong hydrogenation capability, thereby reducing the coverage of CH3O* and shortening its retention time. The intensity of gaseous CH3OH at 1141 cm−1 progressively decreases with extending reaction time, and gaseous CH3OCH3 (1163 cm−1) species and adsorbed CH3OCH3 (1192 cm−1) species with characteristics of ν(OCH3) are detected simultaneously [52], displaying that CH3OH molecules migrate to the spinel surface and dehydrate to form CH3OCH3 molecules. Interestingly, the CH3O* intermediates (1028 cm−1) gradually disappear and the wavenumber values shift from 1141cm−1 (gaseous CH3OH) towards 1192 cm−1 (adsorbed CH3OCH3) within 5 − 30 min of recording [52], showing the dynamic evolution process of the spectra, which indicates that DME is generated via a CH3O*-CH3OHCH3OCH3 route. According to previous literatures, metallic Cu is regarded as the active site for synthesizing methanol, and the (111) crystal plane of Cu-Al spinel is supposed to be the dehydration site of methanol [46,53-55]. The overall peak intensity of the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst prominently enhances in the first 30 min of reaction as compared to the other three catalysts, which is consistent with its higher activity. Combining SEM, TEM, N2O titration, and in-situ DRIFTS analysis, it is believed that the phenomenon is related to the stronger synergistic effect of active sites between Cu NPs and spinel. Additionally, the peaks at 1216 cm−1 and 1228 cm−1 appear within 60–90 min of recording, in which the former belongs to adsorbed CH3OH and the latter corresponds to adsorbed DME [52]. Notably, the bands of adsorbed methanol (1216 cm−1) and CH3OCH3 (1228 cm−1) species over the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst significantly enhance, which is stronger than those of the C0.95M0.05A2 and C0.9M0.1A2 catalysts. This indicates that the octahedral Cu2+ ions in the samples have a positive impact on the sustained release effect of reaction within a certain threshold range. Moreover, the most obvious difference from the other three catalysts is that the intensity of the above two characteristic peaks gradually weaken over the C0.75M0.25A2 catalyst, which is consistent with variation trend of its DME activity. This is related to that excessive Mg doping prompts the massive migration of Cu2+ ions towards octahedron sites, which promotes the formation of numerous non-easily-reducible spinel and results in fewer active copper to be released subsequently. Besides, the low DME selectivity may also be due to the excessive strong base sites, which is not conducive to methanol dehydration and conversion to DME. Compared to the C0.95M0.05A2 and C0.9M0.1A2 catalysts, the reasons for higher catalytic activity and excellent stability of the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst are attributed to larger Cu surface area and smaller active Cu NPs mentioned above, which makes it easy to be dispersed and stabilized on the surface of spinel with acid sites. This improves the proximity between methanol synthesis and methanol dehydration components, indicating the enhanced synergistic effect of the Cu NPs and spinel. Consequently, C0.85M0.15A2 shows overall merits, revealing that an appropriate amount of Mg addition is beneficial for improving the activity and stability of DME. Conclusion In conclusion, the structure-sensitive effect of CuMgAl spinel catalysts in CO hydrogenation to DME are elucidated by tunning the coordination distribution of cations via altering the Mg content. It is found that increasing Mg doping amounts promotes the migration of Cu2+ ions in the samples from tetrahedral sites to octahedral sites, thereby retarding the reduction of copper species and producing small Cu NPs with large Cu surface area, which are anchored on spinel surface. The in-situ DRIFTS results indicate the pathway that CH3OH dehydration to form CH3OCH3, showing the dynamic evolution process of CH3OCH3 formation. However, excessive Mg doping results in lower copper release and excessive strong base sites. These factors jointly suppress the reaction activity. Consequently, C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst achieved higher space-time yield of dimethyl ether (STY DME), superior DME selectivity (64.2 % at 48 h), and excellent stability during consecutive testing of 120 h, indicating that the CuMgAl spinel catalysts with an appropriate Mg doping content are beneficial for CO hydrogenation to DME. Thus, this study greatly broadened the comprehension of structure-activity role, providing ideas for designing and developing efficient and stable catalysts at atomic level. coredata.dc:description: Understanding the structure-activity relationship of catalysis is of critical importance for the design and modulation of catalysts. Herein, Cu-Al spinel catalysts with varied Mg doping levels were synthesized and investigated for CO hydrogenation to dimethyl ether (DME). The results revealed that the coordination distribution of cations in catalysts was effectively regulated by controlling Mg content. Increasing the Mg content facilitated the migration of Cu2+ ions in catalysts from tetrahedral to octahedral sites, enhancing the sustained release performance of copper, and further promoting the stabilization role of Cu nanoparticles by spinel. Importantly, suitable Mg content enhanced the synergistic effect between Cu nanoparticles and spinel active sites, which was conducive to improving DME selectivity. However, excessive Mg doping suppressed the reduction of copper species, and also adversely generated excessive strong base sites. Consequently, an optimal Mg/(Mg+Cu) mole ratio of 0.15 over the C0.85M0.15A2 catalyst exhibited superior selectivity to DME at 64.2 % (at 48 h) and excellent stability during the continuous testing for 120 h. The In-situ DRIFTS experiment confirmed that this reaction involved CH3O* intermediates, and the pathway was elucidated as the hydrogenation of CH3O* to form CH3OH and further dehydration to generate CH3OCH3.
